trans-unit.source: You can use the <codeph>derby.database.fullAccessUsers</codeph> and <codeph>derby.database.readOnlyAccessUsers</codeph> properties to specify the user IDs that have read-write access and read-only access to a database.

seg-source.mrk: You can use the <codeph>derby.database.fullAccessUsers</codeph> and <codeph>derby.database.readOnlyAccessUsers</codeph> properties to specify the user IDs that have read-write access and read-only access to a database.

target.mrk: You can use the <codeph>derby.database.fullAccessUsers</codeph> and <codeph>derby.database.readOnlyAccessUsers</codeph> properties to specify the user IDs that have read-write access and read-only access to a database.

trans-unit.source: If you use SQL authorization (the default with NATIVE authentication), you typically do not use these properties.

seg-source.mrk: If you use SQL authorization (the default with NATIVE authentication), you typically do not use these properties.

target.mrk: If you use SQL authorization (the default with NATIVE authentication), you typically do not use these properties.

trans-unit.source: You can specify multiple user IDs by using a comma-separated list, with no spaces between the comma and the next user ID.

seg-source.mrk: You can specify multiple user IDs by using a comma-separated list, with no spaces between the comma and the next user ID.

target.mrk: You can specify multiple user IDs by using a comma-separated list, with no spaces between the comma and the next user ID.
